docs.lead_paragraph: When children have seizures, doctors are sometimes put in quandaries: should they assume the seizure is epilepsy and begin medicating? Or should they wait and hope it is just an isolated occurrence? A new study may shed some light on the best course. In the current Annals of Neurology, researchers say they have found that when a child has seizures more than once, the diagnosis probably is epilepsy.

headline.main: New Clues for Treating a Child's Seizure

docs.abstract: Study finds that epilepsy is the probable cause when a child has seizures more than once; knowing this may help doctors decide whether the risks of medication are worth it (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The biochemistry of breathing deeply, the one thing an asthmatic cannot do in the midst of the attack, may hold a key to helping doctors treat people who have asthma. A recent study suggests that the mere act of breathing deeply may stretch lung tissue and cause the release of a protective chemical that keeps the airways open. Writing in the Journal of Applied Physiology, researchers from Johns Hopkins University said that if the chemical could be identified, it could possibly be the basis of an asthma drug.

headline.main: In Search of the Deep Breath Chemical

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors routinely overlook a serious sign of osteoporosis, the condition that leaves older people -- primarily women -- susceptible to repeated, often immobilizing bone breaks, according to a study being released today. The study, which looked at 1,162 postmenopausal women who had broken one or both their wrists, found that only a quarter had been evaluated or treated for the disease.

headline.main: Ignoring the Message of Brittle Bones

docs.abstract: New study finds that a broken wrist can be first sign of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and that doctors routinely overlook it; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study offers still more evidence that when it comes to health care, black and white patients do not always get equal treatment. Circulation, the American Heart Association journal, is reporting today that blacks who have had heart attacks are less likely to receive proven treatments to prevent a recurrence, even when they are as inexpensive as aspirin or beta-blockers.
